{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|むぐら}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=むぐら}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> Probably the eastern Japanese form. Compare the alternation in ''ugura'' and ''mugura'' readings in the etymology of {{m|ja|土竜}}.

May ultimately derive from obsolete verb {{m|ja|剥る|tr=mukuru||to peel off, to tear off}}, perhaps related to the way that [[weed]]s are often removed by tearing the plant out.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|むぐら|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|むぐら}}

# any of various [[plant]]s of [[order]] ''[[Gentianales]]'' or ''[[Urticales]]'', that form [[thicket]]s, often have [[thorn]]s and form [[vine]]s, and prefer [[wet]] or [[disturbed]] soils; generally regarded as [[weed]]s
#* {{RQ:Manyoshu|19|4270}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man19Yo.html#4270 here]:
#*: {{lang|ja|'''牟具良'''波布 / 伊也之伎屋戸母 / 大皇之 / 座牟等知者 / 玉之可麻思乎}}
#*: {{lang|ja|'''葎'''延ふ / 賎しき宿も / 大君の / 座さむと知らば / 玉敷かましを}}
#*:: {{lang|ja|'''むぐら''' はふ / いやしき やど も / おほきみ の / まさむ と しらば / たま しかまし を}}
#*:: '''''Mugura''' hafu / iyashiki yado mo / ohokimi no / masamu to shiraba / tama shikamashi wo''
#*::: Even a shabby house surrounded by '''weed thickets''' would be as if strewn with jewels if I knew you were there

=====Usage notes=====
The plants called by this name are many and varied, and include plants such as [[madder]], [[cleaver]], and [[hop]]s.

The reading ''mugura'' appears to be the most common.

{{U:ja:biology|ムグラ}}

{{der-top}}

* {{ja-r|葎の門|むぐら の かど}}: a [[gate]] [[overgrown]] with [[viny]] [[weed]]s
* {{ja-r|葎の宿|むぐら の やど}}: a [[house]] [[overgrown]] with [[viny]] [[weed]]s
* {{ja-r|葎生|むぐらふ}}: a [[dense]] [[growth]] of [[viny]] [[weed]]s
{{der-mid}}
* {{ja-r|大双葉葎|おおふたば むぐら}}: literally “big twin-leaf mugura”, {{taxlink|Diodella teres|species|noshow=1}} or {{vern|poorjoe}}
* {{ja-r|金葎|かな むぐら}}, {{ja-r|葎草|かな むぐら}}: literally “money mugura”, {{taxlink|Humulus japonicus|species|noshow=1}}, {{taxlink|Humulus scandens|species|noshow=1}}: the {{vern|Japanese hop}} plant

* {{ja-r|花八重葎|はな やえ むぐら}}: literally “flowering eight-layer mugura”, {{taxlink|Sherardia arvensis|species|noshow=1}} or {{vern|field madder}}
* {{ja-r|双葉葎|ふたば むぐら}}: literally “twin-leaf mugura”, {{taxlink|Hedyotis diffusa|species|noshow=1}}
* {{ja-r|八重葎|やえ むぐら}}: literally “eight-layer mugura”, {{taxlink|Galium spurium|species|noshow=1}}, the {{vern|false cleaver}} or {{vern|Marin County bedstraw}}
* {{ja-r|四葉葎|よつば むぐら}}: literally “four-leaf mugura”, {{taxlink|Galium trachyspermum|species|noshow=1}}

===Etymology 3===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|もぐら}}
Probably an alteration or dialectal variant of ''mugura'' above. Appears with this reading in the {{lang|ja|本草和名}} (''Honzō Wamyō'', “Japanese Names of the Real Herbs”), a [[pharmacopoeia]] written in 923.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> Still listed as an alternate reading in modern dictionaries.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>
